case_name: Bansidhar Premsukhdas v. State of Rajasthan

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 203 of 1964 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 203 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated January 29, 1963 of Rajasthan High Court in Civil Regular First Appeal No. 29 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated January 29, 1963 of the Rajasthan High Court in Civil Regular First Appeal No. 29 of 1956.

facts.text: Appellant firm Bansidhar Premsukhdas brought suit against State of Rajasthan on March 31, 1953 for recovery of Rs. 86,646/3/- in Court of District Judge, Bharatpur.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant firm Bansidhar Premsukhdas brought a suit which is the subject-matter of this appeal against the State of Rajasthan on March 31, 1953 for the recovery of Rs. 86,646/3/- in the Court of District Judge, Bharatpur.

facts.text: Former State of Bharatpur issued notification on May 18, 1946 offering plots for sale in Mandi.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the appellant was that the former State of Bharatpur with a view to increase the trade and companymerce in the said State decided to establish a Mandi at Bharatpur where at the material time a T.B. Hospital was located, It decided to sell plots for certain fixed amounts and, therefore, issued a numberification on May 18, 1946 offering the plots by public advertisement for sale on certain terms and companyditions.

facts.text: Notification Ex. 4 published in Bharatpur Rajpatra contained cl. 3 granting 25% reduction in customs duty for certain commodities imported/exported in Mandi.

anchor.surface_text: The numberifification--Ex. 4-was published in Bharatpur Rajpatra and one of the companycessions proposed to be granted was embodied in cl. 3 of the numberification which stated If any companymodity is imported from outside into the Mandi and is sold for companysumption within the State, or if any companymodity received in the Mandi from within the State and is exported in both cases, a reduction of 25 in the customs duty prevailing at the time of the import and export of such companymodities will be allowed.

facts.text: Appellant purchased plots Nos. 8 and 9 for Rs. 4,600 at public auction and received sale deeds on October 10, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant purchased plots Nos. 8 and 9 for Rs. 4,600 at a public auction and two sale deeds  sanad nilam  were issued to the appellant on October 10, 1946.

facts.text: Government of Bharatpur, United State of Matsya, and Rajasthan State allowed 25% reduction in customs duty as per cl. 3 until January 16, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of Bharatpur and after its merger, the Government of United State of Matsya and thereafter the present Rajasthan State carried out the promise companytained in cl. 3 of the Bharatpur numberification and allowed reduction of 25 per cent in the customs duty, but on January 16, 1951 the Rajasthan Government issued numberification No. F.4 18  SR/49

facts.text: Rajasthan Government issued notification No. F.4(18)SR/49 on January 16, 1951 abolishing free Mandies and customs concessions.

anchor.surface_text: but on January 16, 1951 the Rajasthan Government issued numberification No. F.4 18  SR/49 which reads as follows Now therefore Government of Rajasthan is hereby pleased to direct that with an immediate effect all free Mandies and Zones including the area companyprising the former Kishangarh State and the Bhim District of the former Rajasthan State shall be abolished and that in companysequence all the Customs companycession hitherto enjoyed by or applicable to these Mandies or Zones shall cease to have force and duties of customs shall be levied and companylected in such Mandies or Zones in accordance with the revised tariff, amended from time to time.

facts.text: Appellant and other traders made representation to Rajasthan Government on January 29, 1951; customs authorities kept 25% as Amanat pending disposal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and other traders thereupon made representation to the Rajasthan Government on January 29, 1951 and pending the disposal of the representation the Customs authorities agreed to keep the amount of 25 per cent by way of Amanat.

facts.text: Rajasthan Government decided on May 25, 1951 that reduction in customs duty could not be conceded.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Rajasthan ultimately decided on May 25, 1951 that the reduction in the customs duty companyld number be companyceded.

facts.text: District Judge Bharatpur decreed appellant's suit on March 31, 1956 holding cl.3 term of sale and Rajasthan bound.

anchor.surface_text: The District Judge of Bharatpur, by his judgment dated March 31, 1956, held that item No. 3 of Bharatpur numberification was a term of sale between the parties and the Rajasthan State was bound by it and the succeeding States have recognised the companycessions granted to the appellant and therefore the suit of the appellant should be decreed.

facts.text: Rajasthan High Court allowed state appeal and dismissed suit on January 29, 1963 holding cl.3 not part of contract and no recognition by Rajasthan.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Rajasthan took the matter in appeal to the Rajasthan Nigh Court which allowed the appeal and dismissed the suit holding that item No. 3 of the Bharatpur numberification was number a part of the companytract of sale, and even if it was held to be a part of the companytract, the successor State of Rajasthan did number recognise it and was number, therefore, bound by it.

facts.text: Petitioner claimed cl.3 of notification Ex.4 dated May 18, 1946 was term of contract of sale.

anchor.surface_text: The first question involved in this appeal is whether cl. 3 of the Bharatpur numberification-Ex. 4, was a term of the companytract of sale between the appellant and the State of Bharatpur. It Was argued on behalf of the appellant that Ex. 4 which is the numberification dated May 18, 1946 regarding the sale of plots by the Bharatpur State was an offer of purchase of plots on terms and companyditions made in that numberification.

facts.text: Respondent claimed cl.3 concession did not form part of contract of sale of plots.

anchor.surface_text: It was submitted that the companycession granted in cl. 3 did number relate to, number did it form a part of the companytract of sale of the plots of the Mandi. It was pointed out that the companycession of 25 per cent reduction in customs duty will number merely enure to the benefit of the purchaser of the plots but also enure to the benefit of the person trading in the shop.

facts.text: Matsya Union formed on March 18, 1948 including Bharatpur.

anchor.surface_text: Before the process of integration began, each Covenanting State was a separate geographical unit for customs purposes and had its own customs laws and barrier. After the formation of the Matsya Union on March 18, 1948 there was a promulgation of the Matsya Customs Ordinance by the Raj Pramukh on September 21, 1948.

facts.text: Matsya Customs Ordinance promulgated on September 21, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: After the formation of the Matsya Union on March 18, 1948 there was a promulgation of the Matsya Customs Ordinance by the Raj Pramukh on September 21, 1948.

facts.text: United State of Rajasthan constituted on May 15, 1949 with merger of Matsya Union.

anchor.surface_text: The United State of Rajasthan was companystituted on May 15, 1949 when there was merger of Matsya Union in the United State of Rajasthan.

facts.text: Rajasthan Regulation of Customs Duties Ordinance No. 16 of 1949 promulgated on August 9, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: On August 9, 1949 the Raj Pramukh promulgated the Rajasthan  Regulation of Customs Duties  Ordinance  1  68 I.A. 100.  2  1959 S.C.R. 729.

facts.text: Supreme Court assumed cl.3 was term of contract but held no recognition by Rajasthan State.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is much force in the argument advanced on behalf of the respondent but it is number necessary to express any companycluded opinion on this aspect of the case. We shall assume in favour of the appellant that cl. 3 of the Bharatpur numberification, Ex. 4, was a term of the companytract of sale of plots 8 and 9 of the Mandi.

facts.text: Supreme Court held successor state not automatically bound by predecessor's contracts without recognition.

anchor.surface_text: It is number companyrect to say as a matter of law that the successor State automatically inherits the rights and obligations of the merged State. There is numberquestion of suborgation-the successor State is number subrogated ipso jure to the companytracts with the merged State.

facts.text: Petitioner claimed implied recognition by continuation of exemptions until January 13, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant it was companytended that there was an implied recognition by the Rajasthan State of the companytractual liability since the exemptions were companytinued upto January 13, 1951 and were revoked with effect from that date by the numberification No. F.4 18 SR/49.

facts.text: Supreme Court held no implied recognition; concessions referable to ordinances, not contract.

anchor.surface_text: The enjoyment of the companycession by the appellant after the formation of the Rajasthan State is clearly referable to the law under which customs companycessions companyld be granted and recognised. This is borne out by the numberification dated January 16, 1951 which appeared in the Rajasthan Raj Patra, which itself refers to ss. 10 and 33 of the Matsya Customs Ordinance No. 14 of 1948 by which customs companycessions were revoked.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Ordinance No.16/1949 superseded any contractual liability.

anchor.surface_text: We shall however ,assume in faboure of the appellant that the State of Rajasthan recognised the companytractual right of the appellant with regard to the exemption of tax. Even upon that assumption the suit of the appellant must fail, for the companytractual liability must be taken to have been superseded by the enactment of the Rajasthan Regulation of Customs Duties  Ordinance No. 16 of 1949 promulgated by the Raj Pramukh on August 9,1949.

facts.text: Bharatpur State acceded to Dominion of India after August 15, 1947 on communications, defence, external affairs.

anchor.surface_text: The former Bharatpur State remained a separate entity till March 18, 1948, though it had acceded to the Dominion of India after August 15, 1947 with respect to three subjects, namely, companymunications, defence and external affairs.

facts.text: Matsya Union formed March 18, 1948 by covenant of February 28, 1948 including Alwar, Bharatpur, Dholpur, Karauli.

anchor.surface_text: In 1948, however, the process of merger in Rajasthan began and the first merger that took place was of the former States of Alwar, Bharatpur, Dholpur and Karauli, which formed the Matsya Union as from March 18, 1948 by a Covenant entered on February 28, 1948.

facts.text: Agreement between Government of India and United State of Rajasthan on February 25, 1950 under Art. 306.

anchor.surface_text: It is the admitted position that the agreement entered between the Government of India and the United State of Rajasthan on February 25, 1950 incorporated certain recommendations of the Federal Finance Enquiry Committee Report 1948-49.

The reason is that the taking over of sovereign powers by a State in respect of territory which was not till then a part of it is an. act of State and the municipal courts recognised by the new sovereign have the power and jurisdiction to investigate and ascertain only such rights as the new sovereign has chosen to recognise or acknowledge and such recognition may be express or may be implied from circumstances. In other words, accession of one State to another is an act of State and the subjects of the former State may claim protection of only such rights as the new sovereign recognises as enforceable by the subjects of the former State in his municipal courts.

concepts.interpretation: Applied to hold that municipal courts can enforce only rights recognized by successor sovereign; contracts of predecessor terminate unless ratified or recognized.

concepts.unlisted_description: Principle governing succession of territory by sovereign states where new sovereign's municipal courts enforce only recognized pre-existing rights.

anchor.surface_text: It is not correct to say as a matter of law that the successor State automatically inherits the rights and obligations of the merged State. There is no question of subrogation-the successor State is not subrogated ipso jure to the contracts with the merged State. The true legal position is that the contract of the predecessor State terminates with the change of sovereignty unless the contract is ratified by the succeeding sovereign State.

concepts.interpretation: Successor state not bound ipso jure by predecessor's contracts; binding only upon express or implied recognition.

concepts.unlisted_label: Successor State's Recognition of Predecessor State's Contracts
concepts.unlisted_description: Rule that contractual obligations of merged or predecessor state bind successor only if recognized.

anchor.surface_text: It is well-established that Parliament or State Legislatures are competent to enact a law altering the terms and conditions of a previous contract or of a grant under which the liability of the Government of India or of the State Governments arises. The legislative competence of Parliament or of the State Legislatures can only be circumscribed by express prohibition contained in the Constitution itself

holdings.text: The successor State does not automatically inherit the rights and obligations under contracts of the predecessor or merged State and is not subrogated ipso jure thereto; the contract terminates upon change of sovereignty unless ratified or recognized by the successor.

anchor.surface_text: We shall proceed, therefore, to consider the next question, namely, whether the term of the contract was binding upon the successor State of Rajasthan on the assumption that cl. 3 of the Bharatpur notification

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act of State doctrine applies to territorial acquisition/merger; municipal courts enforce only rights recognized expressly or impliedly by new sovereign; supported by Judicial Committee precedents (Kamachee Boye, Vajesingji, Rustom Khan) and Supreme Court cases.

holdings.text: There was no recognition, express or implied, by the State of Rajasthan of any contractual liability under clause 3 of the Bharatpur notification.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this argument as correct. Before the process of integration began, each Covenanting State was a separate geographical unit for customs purposes and had its own customs laws and barrier. After the formation of the Matsya Union on March 18, 1948 there was a promulgation of the Matsya Customs Ordinance by the Raj Pramukh on September 21, 1948.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Continuation of concessions post-merger referable to statutory powers (Matsya Customs Ordinance ss.10 & 33; Rajasthan Ordinance s.6) not contract; 1951 notification explicitly invokes those sections; no saving clause for contracts in ordinances.

holdings.text: Clause 3 of the Bharatpur notification, even if a contractual term recognized by Rajasthan, gave rise to no enforceable right as any such contractual liability was superseded by the Rajasthan Regulation of Customs Duties Ordinance No. 16 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: We shall however ,assume in favour of the appellant that the State of Rajasthan recognised the contractual right of the appellant with regard to the exemption of tax. Even upon that assumption the suit of the appellant must fail, for the contractual liability must be taken to have been superseded by the enactment of the Rajasthan Regulation of Customs Duties  Ordinance No. 16 of 1949 promulgated by the Raj Pramukh on August 9,1949.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ordinance comprehensively repealed prior customs laws/usages (s.3) without saving contractual exemptions; introduced uniform tariff (s.4); legislature competent to override prior contracts/grants absent constitutional bar.

holdings.text: Parliament or State Legislatures are competent to enact laws altering or superseding terms of prior governmental contracts or grants, absent express constitutional prohibition.

anchor.surface_text: It is well-established that Parliament or State Legislatures are competent to enact a law altering the terms and conditions of a previous contract or of a grant under which the liability of the Government of India or of the State Governments arises. The legislative competence of Parliament or of the State Legislatures can only be circumscribed by express prohibition contained in the Constitution itself

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plenary legislative power under relevant lists (Art.246); no fetter from contracts/grants; affirmed by Judicial Committee (Thakur Jagannath) and Supreme Court (Umeg Singh, Umaid Mills); Art.295 does not prohibit.

holdings.text: The notification dated January 16, 1951 revoking customs concessions does not violate Article 306 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, it was argued on behalf of the appellant that the notification dated January 16, 1951 revoking the tax concessions was in violation of Art. 306 of the Constitution which provides as follows Notwithstanding anything in the foregoing provisions of this Part or in any other provisions of this Constitution, any State specified in Part B of the First Schedule

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.306 applies to pre-Constitution levies continued by agreement with India; here claim purely contractual not statutory levy; agreement dated Feb 25, 1950 satisfied condition allowing continuance per terms.

precedents.citation: The Secretary of State in Council of India v. Kamachee Boye Saheba 1

anchor.surface_text: In The Secretary of State in Council of India v. Kamachee Boye Saheba 1  the jurisdiction of the courts in India to adjudicate upon the validity of the seizure by the East India Company of the territory of Rajah of Tanjore as an escheat, on the ground that the dignity of the Raj was extinct for want of a male heir, and that the property of the late Rajah lapsed to the British Government, fell to be determined.

precedents.case_name: Secretary of State in Council of India v. Kamachee Boye Saheba
precedents.cited_proposition: Seizure of territory by sovereign power is an act of State over which municipal courts have no jurisdiction
precedents.cited_holding: as the seizure was made by the British Government, acting as a sovereign power, through its delegate, the East India Company, it was an act of State and the Municipal Court had no jurisdiction to inquire into the propriety of the action

precedents.citation: Vajesingji Joravarsingji v. Secretary of State for India in Council 1

anchor.surface_text: In another case-Vajesingji Joravarsingji v. Secretary of State for India in Council 1 -the Judicial Committee observed as follows when a territory is acquired by a sovereign State for the first time that is an act of State, It matters not how the acquisition has been brought about.

precedents.case_name: Vajesingji Joravarsingji v. Secretary of State for India in Council
precedents.cited_proposition: Acquisition of territory by a sovereign is an act of State; only recognized rights enforceable in municipal courts
precedents.cited_holding: Any inhabitant of the territory can make good in the municipal courts established by the new sovereign only such rights as that sovereign has, through his officers, recognised

precedents.citation: Secretary of State v. Sardar Rustom Khan and Others 1

anchor.surface_text: In Secretary of State v. Sardar Rustom Khan and Others 1  a question arose whether the rights of a grantee of certain proprietary rights in lands from the then Khan of Kalat, ceased to be enforceable since the agreement between the Khan and the Agent to the Governor-General in Baluchistan

precedents.case_name: Secretary of State v. Sardar Rustom Khan and Others
precedents.cited_proposition: New sovereign has right to recognize or not recognize existing titles to land
precedents.cited_holding: the Government of India had the right to recognise or not recognise the existing titles to land. In the case of the lands in suit they decided not to recognize them

precedents.cited_proposition: Legislature competent to enact law altering terms of previous contract or grant despite prerogative grants
precedents.cited_holding: the Crown cannot deprive itself of its legislative authority by the mere fact that in the exercise of its prerogative it makes a grant of land; no court can annul enactment within sovereign competence

precedents.citation: Maharaj Umeg Singh and others v. The State of Bombay and others 1

anchor.surface_text: The same principle has been reiterated by this Court in Maharaj Umeg Singh and others v. The State of Bombay and others 1 . It was pointed out that in view of Art. 246 of the Constitution, no curtailment of legislative competence can be spelt out of the terms of clause 5 of the Letters of Guarantee

precedents.case_name: Maharaj Umeg Singh v. State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: No curtailment of legislative competence from guarantees or merger agreements
precedents.cited_holding: in view of Art. 246 of the Constitution, no curtailment of legislative competence can be spelt out of the terms of clause 5 of the Letters of Guarantee given by the Dominion Government to the Rulers of States

precedents.citation: Maharaja Shree Umaid Mills Ltd. v. Union of India 2

anchor.surface_text: This principle also underlies the recent decision of this Court in Maharaja Shree Umaid Mills Ltd. v. Union of India 2  in which it was pointed out that there is nothing in Art. 295 of the Constitution which prohibits Parliament from enacting a law altering the terms

precedents.case_name: Maharaja Shree Umaid Mills Ltd. v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: Parliament can enact law altering terms of contract or grant; Art. 295 does not prohibit
precedents.cited_holding: there is nothing in Art. 295 of the Constitution which prohibits Parliament from enacting a law altering the terms and conditions of a contract or of a grant under which the liability of the Government of India arises

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this argument as correct. Before the process of integration began, each Covenanting State was a separate geographical unit for customs purposes and had its own customs laws and barrier. After the formation of the Matsya Union on March 18, 1948 there was a promulgation of the Matsya Customs Ordinance by the Raj Pramukh on September 21, 1948.

We are, therefore, of the opinion that the High Court has rightly taken the view, upon an analysis of the evidence adduced in the case, that there was numberrecognition of the companytractual liability by the succeeding State of Rajasthan.
ratpur State remained a separate entity till March 18, 1948, though it had acceded to the Dominion of India after August 15, 1947 with respect to thre

edges.explanation: Holding that contractual liability was superseded directly addresses the issue of supersession by the ordinance.

anchor.surface_text: We shall however ,assume in favour of the appellant that the State of Rajasthan recognised the contractual right of the appellant with regard to the exemption of tax. Even upon that assumption the suit of the appellant must fail, for the contractual liability must be taken to have been superseded by the enactment of the Rajasthan Regulation of Customs Duties  Ordinance No. 16 of 1949 promulgated by the Raj Pramukh on August 9,1949.

We are, therefore, of the opinion that the High Court has rightly taken the view, upon an analysis of the evidence adduced in the case, that there was numberrecognition of the companytractual liability by the succeeding State of Rajasthan.

edges.explanation: Holding h4 on legislatures' competence to enact superseding laws supports the validity and effect of concept c6 as such a provision.
General holding on legislative competence to supersede prior contracts supports specific holding that this ordinance superseded the contractual liability.
Legislative competence holding addresses whether contractual liability could be superseded by the state ordinance.

anchor.surface_text: It is well-established that Parliament or State Legislatures are competent to enact a law altering the terms and conditions of a previous contract or of a grant under which the liability of the Government of India or of the State Governments arises. The legislative competence of Parliament or of the State Legislatures can only be circumscribed by express prohibition contained in the Constitution itself

We are, therefore, of the opinion that the High Court has rightly taken the view, upon an analysis of the evidence adduced in the case, that there was numberrecognition of the companytractual liability by the succeeding State of Rajasthan.

Lastly, it was argued on behalf of the appellant that the notification dated January 16, 1951 revoking the tax concessions was in violation of Art. 306 of the Constitution which provides as follows Notwithstanding anything in the foregoing provisions of this Part or in any other provisions of this Constitution, any State specified in Part B of the First Schedule

We are, therefore, of the opinion that the High Court has rightly taken the view, upon an analysis of the evidence adduced in the case, that there was numberrecognition of the companytractual liability by the succeeding State of Rajasthan.
